topics.title: [S00032] Loud Audio Amplifier
topics.description: Turn up the volume without distortion and drain a 9V battery quickly.
topics.coverage_text:
In this video I'm going to show you how to build a simple audio amplifier that can power
nearly any speaker. For less than $3 in parts it gets surprisingly loud. This tutorial was

topics.title: Adding a Filter Capacitor
topics.description: Use a 100uF capacitor to filter out noise from the power supply.
topics.coverage_text:

topics.title: Output Filtering
topics.description: Add a 1k0uF capacitor to ensure no DC voltage reaches your speaker.
topics.coverage_text:
speaker. This chip has been around for decades and it's still used to this day in products
like computer speakers and portable stereos. So everyone who works with electronics needs
to know about this chip. The maximum power output is roughly 1 watt, which doesn't sound like
much in a world full of deceptive marketing, but trust me, 1 watt going into a speaker is

topics.title: Analyzing the Output
topics.description: Use an oscilloscope to identify noise and oscillation in the audio signal.
topics.coverage_text:
more than enough power to fill an entire living room full of sound.
The first thing you're going to need is a 3.5mm audio plug attached to a cable. There
are many ways to get this. You could solder wires onto a plug, or cut up an extension cable,
but I think the cheapest way to do this is to just cut up headphones from the dollar store.

topics.title: Fixing Oscillation Issues
topics.description: Add a 0.1uF capacitor to filter out high-frequency oscillation.
topics.coverage_text:
After I was done being a stripper, I used some sandpaper to remove the insulation on the left
and right signal wires. And I soldered on some thicker wire to make it easier to connect
the cable to a breadboard. I also twisted the two ground wires together.
Next, we're going to implement the simplest possible stereo to mono conversion circuit.

topics.title: Conclusion and Future Learning
topics.description: Build an amplifier for under $3 and explore more electronics resources online.
topics.coverage_text:
It's just putting 1kohm resistors in series with the audio channels, then joining the
ends together. Now, this is definitely not the best way to do stereo to mono, as we're
just averaging the signals here, but the point of this project is to create the simplest amplifier
possible, and this trick works surprisingly well. Next, you're going to need an LM386 chip.
